===Etymology===
From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=たんな'}} {{m|ltc|旦那|tr=dɑ̀n nɑ}}, {{m|ltc|檀那|tr=dhɑn nɑ}}, both used as [[transliteration]]s of {{etyl|sa|ja|sort=だんな}} {{m|sa|दान||generosity, giving, donating}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref> Ultimately cognate with {{cog|en|donate}}.

===Pronunciation===
{{ja-pron|yomi=goon|acc=0|acc_ref=DJR|だんな}}

===Alternative forms===
* {{ja-l|檀那}}

===Noun===
{{ja-noun|だんな}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=だんな|Buddhism}} [[generosity]] as one of the Buddhist perfections ({{m|sa|पारमिता}})
# {{lb|ja|sort=だんな|Buddhism}} a [[donation]] of [[money]], [[goods]], or [[service]] to [[monk]]s or a [[temple]]
# {{lb|ja|sort=だんな|Buddhism}} a person who makes such a donation: a [[patron]]
# {{lb|ja|sort=だんな|archaic}} in the Japanese medieval period, [[overnight]] [[visitor]]s to a [[shrine]] or [[temple]]
# broadly, a [[patron]], a [[husband]], a [[master]]:
## {{lb|ja|sort=だんな|honorific}} a [[master]] of [[servant]]s, a [[boss]] of [[employee]]s, the master of the [[house]]
## {{lb|ja|sort=だんな|honorific}} by extension, an honorific for one's own or someone else's [[husband]]

## {{lb|ja|sort=だんな|honorific}} also by extension, used by shopkeepers to address a male [[customer]] or by an [[artisan]] to refer to one's own [[school]] or [[lineage]]
## {{lb|ja|sort=だんな|honorific}} a term used by a [[concubine]], [[mistress]], or [[geisha]] to refer to one's own [[patron]]: a [[sugar daddy]]
## {{lb|ja|sort=だんな|honorific}} a term used by [[female]] servants to refer to the [[mistress]] of the house

====Usage notes====
The {{m|en|husband}}, {{m|en|master}}, and {{m|en|patron}} senses may be the most commonly used meanings in modern Japanese.

When referring to another person's husband, this term is often suffixed with {{ja-l|様||sama}} as {{lang|ja|旦那様}} (''danna-sama'').

The {{m|en|patron}} sense in Buddhist contexts is often spelled {{ja-l|檀那}}.

====Synonyms====
* {{sense|donation of money, goods, or service}} {{ja-l|布施|ふせ|fuse}}
* {{sense|artisanal lineage}} {{ja-l|檀那流|だんなりゅう|danna ryū}}
* {{sense|husband, boss, master of the house}} {{ja-l|主人|しゅじん|shujin}}
* {{sense|a woman's patron, a sugar daddy}} {{ja-l|パトロン||patoron}}

====Derived terms====
{{der-top}}
* {{ja-l|旦那ぶる|だんなぶる|dannaburu}}: to [[act]] or [[behave]] [[masterful]]ly
* {{ja-l|旦那芸|だんなげい|dannagei}}: an art or cultural pursuit studied by someone who is [[well-to-do]] as a means of passing the time
* {{ja-l|旦那寺|だんなでら|dannadera}}: a [[Buddhist]] [[temple]] supported by a household that has [[convert]]ed to [[Buddhism]]
* {{ja-l|旦那持ち}}, {{ja-l|旦那持|だんなもち|danna mochi}}: having [[patronage]]; someone that has [[patronage]] (generally female, such as a ''[[geisha]]'')
* {{ja-l|旦那取り}}, {{ja-l|旦那取|だんなどり|dannadori}}: taking a master, as a servant; becoming a [[mistress]] or [[concubine]]
* {{ja-l|旦那場|だんなば|dannaba}}: a good [[customer]]
{{der-bottom}}

====Idioms====
{{der-top|Idioms}}
* {{ja-l|旦那を取る|だんなをとる|danna o toru}}: "to take a [[master]]", to find a [[patron]] → generally refers to a ''[[geisha]]'' or other female finding a male to look after their needs
* {{ja-l|旦那の一気働きは鬼も叶わぬ|だんなのいっきばたらきはおにもかなわぬ|danna no ikkibataraki wa oni mo kanawanu}}: "not even the devil can match the master for getting down to hard work" → someone who rarely has to get involved in actual work will work very hard when they have to roll up their sleeves and do it themselves
* {{ja-l|旦那の喧嘩は槍持ちから|だんなのけんかはやりもちから|danna no kenka wa yarimochi kara}}: "fights between masters start from the guardsmen" → disputes between the powerful often arise from minor disputes among their employees or followers: petty foibles can lead to big battles
* {{ja-l|旦那の好きな赤烏帽子|だんなのすきなあかえぼし|danna no suki na akaeboshi}}: "the master's beloved red ''eboshi'' hat" → {{m|ja|烏帽子|tr=eboshi}} are traditionally black, so a red ''eboshi'' indicates someone willing to go against tradition: no matter how strange, one must follow one's master
* {{ja-l|旦那の前より釜の前|だんなのまえよりかまのまえ|danna no mae yori kama no mae}}: "(better) in front of a pot than in front of a master" → it is better to be one's own master, even if it means being poor
* {{ja-l|旦那三百我五百|だんなさんびゃくわれごひゃく|danna sanbyaku ware gohyaku}}: "three hundred for the master, five hundred for me" → people generally think of their own benefit more than the benefit of their masters or bosses
{{der-bottom}}
